title: 108_s1896
content: The "Tax Relief Extension Act of 2003" amends the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. It includes extensions for certain expiring provisions such as parity in mental health benefits limits and a credit for electricity produced from renewable resources. The "Tax Relief Extension Act of 2003" amends the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 by extending provisions like the credit for electricity from renewable resources, work opportunity credit, and welfare-to-work credit with amended effective dates. The Tax Relief Extension Act of 2003 extends provisions such as the welfare-to-work credit with an amended effective date of June 30, 2004. Additionally, there is a taxable income limit on percentage depletion for oil and natural gas produced from marginal properties. The Tax Relief Extension Act of 2003 extends provisions, including changes to the allowance for depletion by shifting the effective date to July 1, 2004. The amendments apply to taxable years starting after December 31, 2003. SEC. 106 amends section 1397E(e) to increase the limit to $200,000,000 for bonds issued after December 31, 2003. SEC. 107 changes the tax date for distilled spirits to July 1, 2004. SEC. 108 introduces a deduction for corporate donations of computer technology. SEC. 108 amends the deduction for corporate donations of computer technology to apply to contributions made after June 30, 2004. Section 30 is amended to change dates for deductions, with amendments applying after June 30, 2004. Additionally, a conforming amendment changes dates to apply after July 1, 2007. The effective date for the amendments made to Section 30 is after December 31, 2003, with changes to deduction dates applying after July 1, 2007. SEC. 110. DEDUCTION FOR CLEAN-FUEL VEHICLES AND CERTAIN REFUELING PROPERTY. Section 179A is amended to change dates for property placed in service, with amendments effective for property placed in service after December 31, 2003. SEC. 111 amends the deduction for school teachers' expenses, increasing the amount to $125 for a specific period. The effective date is after December 31, 2003. SEC. 112 discusses the availability of medical savings accounts. SEC. 112 amends the availability of medical savings accounts by changing the cut-off year to 2004. Conforming amendments are also made for various years. The effective date for these changes is January 1, 2004. SEC. 113 extends the termination date for environmental remediation costs to June 30, 2004. SEC. 114 expands the Work Opportunity Tax Credit to the New York Liberty Zone for individuals starting work after December 31, 2003. SEC. 115 introduces temporary special rules for the taxation of life insurance companies. SEC. 115 amends subsection (j) of section 809 to include 2004 for taxation of life insurance companies. The amendment applies to taxable years starting after December 31, 2003. The amendment extends various deadlines for tax-related provisions from December 31, 2003, to June 30, 2004, including the designation of zones, tax-exempt economic development bonds, and the zero percent capital gains rate. The deadlines for tax-related provisions have been extended from December 31, 2003, to June 30, 2004, including changes to the First-Time Homebuyer Credit and effective date amendments. SEC. 117 of the Taxpayer Relief Act of 1997 is amended to change the reporting period to end before July 1, 2004. This amendment applies to disclosures made after the enactment of the Act. The Taxpayer Relief Act of 1997 is amended to include a new taxable vaccine against hepatitis A. The effective date for these amendments is set to apply to sales and uses after a specified time period following the enactment of the Act. The delivery date for sales made after the effective date will be considered the sale date. SEC. 202. Addition of influenza vaccines to taxable list. The amendment adds trivalent influenza vaccines to the list of taxable vaccines. The effective date applies to sales and uses after a specified time frame or when the Secretary of Health and Human Services lists any influenza vaccine for compensation purposes. The amendment adds trivalent influenza vaccines to taxable vaccines, with the delivery date considered the sale date for sales before the effective date. SEC. 203. Extension of transfers of excess pension assets to retiree health accounts. Amendments are made to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 and the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974, extending expiration dates and updating references to the Tax Relief Extension Act of 2003. Amendments update references to the Tax Relief Extension Act of 2003 by changing the expiration dates. SEC. 204 extends IRS user fees by changing the termination date from December 31, 2004, to December 31, 2011. This amendment applies to requests made after the enactment of the Act.
